triples.name: Justified true belief
triples.relevance: The paper uses the justified true belief (JTB) framework as the foundational concept for analyzing knowledge.

triples.name: Justification (epistemology)
triples.relevance: The paper develops a theory of justification in epistemology, examining how beliefs can be rationally justified.

triples.name: Epistemology
triples.relevance: The paper is grounded in epistemological philosophy, studying the nature and justification of knowledge.

triples.name: Foundationalism
triples.relevance: The paper employs foundation-theoretic epistemology, where knowledge is justified through foundational rational arguments.

triples.name: Deductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper discusses deduction as a primary form of justification, though notes it cannot convey certainty about most beliefs.

triples.name: Inductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper examines induction as a form of reasoning for justification that can only convey probability, not certainty.

triples.name: Abductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper discusses abduction as an inferential method that, like induction, cannot provide certain justification.

triples.name: Lottery paradox
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes the lottery paradox as one of two key paradoxes revealing tensions in commonsense knowledge intuitions.

triples.name: Gettier problem
triples.relevance: The paper examines the Gettier paradox as a fundamental challenge to the justified true belief account of knowledge.
